en: Interview with Lisa and Hannah Oakley, 2020-01-11

Interview with Lisa and Hannah Oakley, mother and daughter residents of Gatlinburg. They discuss their life in Gatlinburg before recounting the events of the wildfires. Splitting up during the evacuation, they eventually reunited, and used social media to follow the disaster as it was unfolding. The two also talk about the lasting impact the fire had on individuals and the city as a whole. This is a representative quote from the interview: "[Gatlinburg] is so cut off from everything else that it's almost like its own little world. You don't expect anything to happen, so I think after [the fire], it made everybody a little bit more aware this stuff really can and will happen, and you can't tell when it's going to."

en: Interview Questions
Can you state your names and give us an idea of how long you have been in the Gatlinburg area?
Did both of you go to Pi Beta Phi Elementary?
What do each of you do here in town?
Do both of you live in Gatlinburg? Where?
When did you first become aware that there was a fire on Chimney Tops?
When did you first notice that it was drifting towards Gatlinburg instead of the fire being background noise?
Can you describe the eerie feeling of driving through the ash?
Were you concerned? What time did you head to your mom's house?
Can you describe what you heard on the interviews about the fire?
Did you know that Gatlinburg was on fire at this point?
Did you see any ash coming down?
Did you evacuate with your mother?
What was your reaction when Facebook started having so many posts about the fire?
What was it like to watch real life communication unfold on Facebook about the disaster?
How close did the fire get to the sanctuary?
Did the Presbyterian church next door, suffer any damage?
What did you think after you saw the damage to Gatlinburg?
Did you have friends or acquaintances that lost their homes?
When you met old friends who lost their homes, what did you say?
How would you assess the recovery efforts of Gatlinburg as a whole?
Did the fire have any kind of lasting emotional or financial impact?
Do you think this fire can happen again?
How would you say that this fire shaped community relations?
How would you say that this fire shaped community relations?
Was there any good outcome from this event?
Could you give us your opinion as an historian about what the value may be for a project like this?
Is there anything that we haven't touched on that you would like to share?
Do you think the urban legend about the unaccounted deaths will persist?
